title: Animal lover Ernie Bowden died at 105 and left his Bellevue Hill house to nine charities
text:
The Bellevue Hill home of the late Ernest Bowden — who died in May 2017 at the age of 105 — has hit the market with a $3 million guide.

And the proceeds are set to go to nine animal charities.

The original Californian bungalow at 165 O’Sullivan Rd has just two bedrooms but Sotheby’s managing director Michael Pallier expects young families to see the potential of the 553 sqm block.

Mr Bowden’s friend — and cousin by marriage — the entertainer Sylvia Raye, who famously sang to the troops during the Vietnam War, is ensuring most of the proceeds from the sale go to nine animal charities.

“Ernie loved birds and he also had cats during his life — at one stage he had five of them,” Ms Raye said.

The man everyone called Ernie lived in the house for 90 years, moving with his parents on his 16th birthday in 1927 and starting his job as a scientific precision instrument maker at the CSIRO on the same day.

He was evidently a humble bloke who lived quietly — he didn’t like to waste anything so he used the Wentworth Courier as a placemat, folding up the pages neatly after each meal and throwing the remains in the bin.

But in 2014 his oft-made comment to have “come from royalty” was proved true.

Authors and relatives Jane Stevens and Belinda Dettman wrote in The Secret Princess that Mr Bowden was the long-lost great-grandson of Wilhelm, the first emperor of Germany.

And his father, Robert Bowden, was the official government photographer at the time the Sydney Harbour Bridge opened in 1932. “Ernie saw de Groot cut the ribbon,” Ms Raye said.

Mr Bowden had never married. His great passion was his clocks — he had five grandfather clocks — and his barometers which were his “children”.

Mechanic Ron Bell, 66, still lives in an original 1922-built bungalow next door at No. 163, though he’s just leasing it from the new owner who paid $3.3 million for it at auction last December after the death of his mother, Mabel.

Mr Bell expects his old home and Mr Bowden’s to have a date with a bulldozer.

“It’s certainly the end of an era … the older homes are disappearing,” he lamented.

For his part, Ms Raye said old Ernie told her: “I want it to be bulldozed … I want to raise as much money as we can for the animals.”

At the grand age of 102, Mr Bowden was declared Australia’s oldest animal activist by Animals Australia.

Ms Raye helped him prepare a poster slamming the live trade of animals which went viral on Facebook.

“He received over 40,000 likes from all over the world,” Ms Raye said.

Ernie’s house is just two doors from the five-bedroom luxury Hamptons-inspired residence sold by News Corp Australasia executive chairman Michael Miller and his wife Tonya for $6,575,000 a year ago.

The result of that auction, through Mr Pallier, had been $570,000 above reserve. Pub baron Justin Hemmes had been the underbidder.
description: The Bellevue Hill home of the late Ernest Bowden, who died in May 2017 at the age of 105, has a $3 million guide, with the proceeds set to go to nine animal charities.
